IF the ground be plaine and that you may goe so neare
to the base of the altitude, that the plum-line may fall on the part one of right shadow; then measuring the distance from the midst of your foote to the base thereof, multiplying that measure by twelue, and adding thereto the height from your eye to the ground, you haue the true height of that altitude: or letting the Sunne beame pierce through the visuall sights of the plum-line, falling at libertie on the part one of right shadow, measuring and multiplying that measure by twelue, and diuiding by the parts whereon the plum-line hangs, the quotient wil tel you the true height of the same altitude: for this is a generall rule, that looke what part of right shadow is cut by the threed or plum-line, the altitude or vpright height to bee measured is more than that shadow, by such proportion as twelue exceedeth the part or diuision of the skale where the threed or plum-line was found.

If the threed bee found to fall on the part 2. of right shadow, measure the distance from the midst of your foote to the base of the altitude, sixe times that measure is the height of the same, adding the height from the eye to the ground, for the part 2. is contained in 12. (the diuisions of the scale) six times; or what part soeuer it fal on of right shadow, look how oft that part is contained in 12. so many times as that measure is from the midst of your foote to the base, euer adding the height from your eye, is the true height of the thing you measure. Or in briefe, if the plum-line fall on the part 3. working as is said, foure times that measure is the height of the altitude.

Or if it fall on the part 4. then three times; if on the part 5. two times ⅖ parts of the shadow is the height: if
on the part 6, 2 times: if on the part 7, once & 1/7: if on the part 8, once and ½: if on the part 9, once ⅓: if on the part 10, once and ⅕: if on the part 11, once 1/11 part of the shadow. All these mensurations be to be wrought within the length of the altitude.

In measuring by the points of contrary shadow, which sheweth to measure all altitudes without the length therof, you must multiply the length of the shadow by the point or diuision of the scale wheron the threed falleth, diuiding the result by 12, the quotient will shew you the true height of the altitude.

Or without shadow, goe so neare to the same that you imagine you are neare within the length thereof, lifting vp the Quadrant orderly, going to or from the same, till through the sights you espie the top or highest part of the altitude, the threed falling on the part 12, standing vpright with your body, and at the midst of your foote make a marke, then goe directly backeward from the same, till through the visuall sights you espie the highest part againe, the threed falling on the part 6 of contrary shadow; and at the midst of your foot make another marke, the distance between those two markes adioyning thereto the height from your eye to the ground, is the true height of the altitude: and your furthest station is twice the length of the height of the altitude, wanting the height from your eye to the ground, which you must euer adde to the worke.

div.head: Another way.
div.p:
If at the first station the threed fall on the part 6 of contrarie shadow, & at the second station on the part 4, the distance betweene those two markes is the height,
adding as before, and the furthest station is three times the length of the altitude you measure from the base therof, the ground being plaine.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: If at the first station the threed fall on the part 4, of contrary shadow, and at the second on the part 3, then the distance betweene your two standings is the height desired, adding as afore, and the furthest station is distant from the base of the altitude foure times the length or height thereof.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: If at the first station the threed fall on the part 3, and at the next the part 2, then the distance betweene those two standings is twice as much as the length of the altitude, excepting the height from your eie to the ground, and your furthest station shall be from the base of the altitude sixe times the height thereof.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: If at the first your threed fall on the part 2 of contrarie shadow, and at the second on the part one, the space between the 2 standings, shall be sixe time the length or height of the altitude, or the 6 part of that measure shall be the height thereof; and your furthest station shall be distant from the base thereof, twelue times the height thereof.
And note that if the scale were diuided vnto 60, 100, or 1000 diuisions, by so much further from the thing to be measured might you find out the height thereof.

div.head: How you may likewise by the parts of right shadow in the scale by the ayde of two places finde out any approachable height.
div.p: PLace your Quadrant handsomly to your eye, til beholding the extream of the altitude through the visuall sights, your threed falling on the part 12, and at the middle of your foot make a marke, and going nearer to the base of the altitude directly forward, beholding the extreame or highest part of the altitude, the plummet cutting the part 6, at the middle of your foote make another marke, double that space, and thereto adioyne the height from your eye to your foote, the summe is the true height of the altitude.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: Lift vp your Quadrant as afore, the plummet cutting the part 12, and going nearer till it cut the part 8, marking the middle of both your standings, measure that distance, and triple that measure, and thereto adde the height from your eye, you haue the height.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: Let the threed cut the part 12 and 9, marking the middle of both your standings, measure the distance, quatriple that measure, and adde the height from your eye, you haue the height.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: If at the first station the threed cut the part 12, and at the next station the part 10, sixe times the distance of the 2 station is the height, adding as aforesaid.
Or if at the first it fall on the part 12, and at the second on the part 1, then 12 times the distance of the 2 stations is the height desired, adding the height from your eie to the ground.

div.head: A generall rule how you may by a Gunners Quadrant measure all heights by Arithmeticall skill.
div.p: NOte what point or diuision of the skale the threed falleth on, your eye beholding through the visual sights of your rule the iust top or extreame part of the altitude, if the threed fall on the parts of right shadow, then multiply the distance from the midle of your foot to the base by 12, and diuide by the parts of the skale wherein the threed fell, adding thereto the height from your eye to the ground, you haue the height. But if the threed fall on the parts of contrarie shadow, then multiply the distance from the middle of your foote to the base by those parts, and diuide by 12, and to the quotient adde the height from your eie to the ground, you haue the altitude likewise.

div.head: Example.
div.p: SVppose the plum-line cut the part 5 of contrary shadow, the distance from the middle of your foote to the base of the altitude 110 foot, that multiplyed by 5, is 550 foote, the which diuided by 12, yeeldes in the quotient 45 foot ⅚, to which adde fiue foote, the height from your eye to your foote, the summe is fiftie foot ⅚, the true height of that measure.

Or suppose the threed fall on the part 6 of right shadow,
the distance from the middle of your standing to the base of the Altitude 24 foote, which multiplied by 12 makes 288, diuided by 6, the quotient is 48 foot, to which fiue foote added, the supposed height from your eye to the ground is 53 foote, the height of that altitude.

Note in euery working, whether the ground at your standing be leuell or not with the base of the altitude, if it be either higher or lower than the base, the plum-line falling on the line of leuell, wil tell you what part of the base is leuell with your eye.

div.head: A generall rule to measure the length or distance of the parts or part of any Altitude.
div.p:
You must first finde out the height of either part of the thing you would measure, by the rules aforesaid, in taking the length or height of the top and base of the same, abating the lesse out of the more, the remaine is your desire. Or setting vp perpendicularly a Gunners Iauelin, Halbard or staffe, diuided into equall parts, a little within the length of the height of the altitude you would measure, mouing your selfe from the same backwards, either lying on your back, or stooping your eye low towards the ground, till you can espie the extreame tops or ends of the altitude and staffe in a streight line from your eie, and then not mouing your eie, view the lowest part of the same thing you would measure, and suppose the visuall line cut or passe by the third part or diuision of the staffe, which imagine to bee diuided into 8 equall parts, or 8 foot the length therof;
and that the distance from your eye to the base of the staffe is eighteene foote, and the distance from your eie to the base of the altitude is 120 foot, frame the rule of 3. saying, if eighteene foot the space from your eye to the staffe yeelde 120, foote which is the distance to the base of the altitude, what will 3 foote? multiply 120 by 3, ariseth 360, diuide by 18, the quotient is 20 foote, the height of that part of the altitude you desire to measure.

div.head: A rule how by the degrees of the Quadrant by knowing a part or portion of the base or lowest part of any Altitude, to find out the height of the same.
div.p:
GOe so neare to the thing whose height you would measure, setting the rule to your eie, so as the plumline falling on the line of leuell, may point equall with the base of the altitude, or else note some marke of the altitudes base, where your visuall sight points at the threed falling on the line of leuell; then raise the quadrant higher, so standing still as the threed may fall on the first degree thereof, and looking through the sights, marke where the visuall line points at, the distance betweene those two markes is to be measured. And lastly, lifting vp your Quadrant, beholding the top thereof through the sights, marke vpon what degree the threed falleth: and so by knowing the distance and height of the first degree, you may easily by the golden rule find out the height of the altitude. Example. Say or suppose the threed falleth on the sixt degree of the quadrant: when you behold the top thereof through the visuall sights, and the knowne distance of one degree is 8 foote, then
say, if on degree yeeld 8 foot, what sixe? you shal haue 48 foote, the true height thereof.

div.head: How you may by a Gunners Iauelin or Halbard, or any straight staffe, finde out any approchable height by the shadow.
div.p: SVppose the Gunners Iauelin be 8 foote in length, fet the same vp perpendicularly, and measure the length of the shadow the same casts, which measure suppose to be twelue foot. Then measure the length of the altitudes shadow, which suppose to be 60 foote. Then framing the rule of Proportion, saying, if 12 foote knowne shadow yeeld 8 foote height, what 60? and so multiplying 60 by 8, and diuiding by 12, the quotient is 40, shewing the height of the altitude is iust 40 foot in height; the like rule is in Vegetios.

div.head: Another way without shadow by any streight thing perpendicularly erected to finde out the height of any approchble Altitude.
div.p:
SEt vp a staffe or gunners Iauelin perpendicularly as afore, somewhat within the length of the altitude, going from the same, and lying on your backe, moue your selfe to or from the same, till you can espie the very end of the Iauelin, and the top of the marke in a streight line from your eye: suppose the distance from your eye to the staffe 12 foote, and the distance from your eye to the base of the altitude 60 foote, and the height of the Iauelin 8 foot; say, if twelue foot the space
from your eye to the staffe yeeld 8 foot height, what wil 60 foot (the distance from your eie to the base of the altitude?) Multiply and diuide, your quotient is 40, as afore, shewing the altitude of the thing to be measured. The like rule is in Master Digs his Geometricall booke called Pantometria; who sheweth also in the same, how by any two staues of equall length ioyned in a right angle squirewise, you may find any altitude, by setting the one end thereof to your eye, going to or from the thing to be measured, vntill you can by the points or ends of the other staffe with one eye view both the base and top of the altitude, making a mark at the midst of your foot, the distance from that mark to the base is the iust height of the thing you seek to measure.

Many mo waies there be to finde out heights, both by the Quadrant, squire, triangle, glasse, staffe, &c. which I let passe: the vnexperienced by these few easie conclusions may the sooner attaine the rest.

div.head: How you may by the helpe of the Quadrant from any plaine platforme know the distance therefrom to any marke you are to shoote at.
div.p:
LAy your Quadrant flat vpon some stoole, or take a short staffe with a skrew in the end thereof, erecting the same perpendicularly, and put the Quadrant vpon the same skrew; then by the edge of the rule turning the same to the marke whose distance you would measure, or through the visuall sights on the rule espie the marke, and at your standing set vp a Gunners staffe or Iauelin; then turning your body crosse the same, not altering
the rule and Quadrant by the line of leuell, on the edge of the Quadrant espie some other marke athwart the first, and set vp the second staffe, the distance whereof suppose to be 60 foote; then comming to the first station where the quadrant is placed, viewing by the edge of the rule through the visuall sights, some other mark in a streight line back from your first station, whose distance suppose 100 feete, and there erect vp the 3 staffe, and so the first and the third staffe will bee in a streight line with the mark, then with a squire or remouing the quadrant to the 3 station, turning the right angle or line of leuell ouerthwart towards the second station, so as the visuall line may bee parallell to the line that crosseth from the first station to the second, there set vp the 4 staffe, so as the visuall line passing from the same, and running by the second staffe, may crosse the marke or end in a point there with the first visuall line, the distance betweene these two last stations suppose 65 feet, the staues thus placed in order abade 60 feete, the distance btweene the first and second station from 65 the distance between the 3 and 4 staues, the remaine is 5 for your deuisor; then multiply the said 65 by 100, the
diagram showing how to measure distance with a quadrant and gunner's staff or javelin distance from the first to the 3, ariseth 6500, the which diuided by 5, the quotient is 1300 feete, the distance
from the first staffe, to the marke. Behold the figure before, where the cipher O, represents the marke, the vnite 1. your first staffe or station, the figure 2 the second staffe, the figure 3 the third staffe, and the figure 4 the fourth staffe.

div.head: How you may another way by the Quadrant and your Gunners staffe diuided into euen portions, tell the distance to any marke neare hand that you are to shoote at.
div.p: SEt the angle of your Quadrant vpon the very point or top of your staffe, the said staffe perpendicularly erected, and through the sights on your ruler espie the marke whose distance you desire to measure, letting a long threed or small line fal to the ground from the center of the Quadrant whereon the plum line hangs, which threed must be drawne along the line of leuell or edge of the Quadrant to the ground, marking where the threed points at on the ground, beholding the mark through the visuall sights in the rule of the Quadrant: and looke what proportion that part of ground between the staffe and where the threed pointed at, hath to the staffe, the same proportion shall the length to the marke haue to the height or length of the staffe.

div.head: Example.
div.p:
THe Gunners staffe AB, suppose to bee eight foote long, and the distance betweene the staffe and the ground where the threed points you to (being the space CB) is but 8 inches, therefore looke what proportion CB beareth to the length of the staffe (which reduced
into inches will be 96 inches) the same proportion shall the length to the marke D haue to the staffe, which by the golden rule is thus found. If 8 inches yeeld 96 inches, what will 96 inches? multiply 96 by 96, ariseth 9216 inches, diuided by 8, yeeldes in the quotient 1152 inches, the distance from the staffe to the marke: and note that the higher the pole or staffe is, the further may you measure by this rule; behold the figure.

div.head: How you may by a Gunners Quadrant readily measure the length of anie wall or curtaine, or the distance betwixt any two markes in the same.
div.p:
GO directly towards one of the said markes, that by supposition you are distant from the same about the length betwixt the two markes whose distance you would measure, laying your Quadrant flat vpon some stoole, or placing the same vpon the skrew of the staffe aforenamed perpendicularly erected, mouing the same to or from the marke you stand against, placing the Quadrant so, as the visuall sight passing from the center of the Quadrant by the line of leuell, may direct you to
the said mark, & the visuall line passing from the center of the Quadrant by the 12 point or diuision of the scale which is the hipothemisal line, may direct you to the other marke; and then the length of your standing to the marke which the line of leuell directs you to, is from the same iust the distance betweene the 2 markes you meane to measure. Then looking athwart by the other edge of the Quadrant, or through the sights on your rule, espie some other marke on the ground directly against the marke you meane to measure, and the visuall line passing betweene your station and the said marke wil be parallell to the wall or line passing betweene the two markes whose distance you would measure. Then remouing your quadrant before the other marke, placing the same so as the line of leuell may direct you to the said marke, and the line passing by your sights on your ruler may direct you to your first station, the distance betwixt your two stations being measured, is the iust space betwixt the two markes you seeke to measure, as the demonstration hereunder sheweth, where the
diagram showing the use of a gunner's quadrant to measure distance
line AB, sheweth the length or distance I would measure supposed to be 100 paces, and the like number is found both in the line CD, as also in the lines CA and DB, which proues the worke to be truely wrought.

div.head: How you may by the former conclusion at one station measure the distance to both the former markes.
div.p: THe distance from your standing C, to the marke A, which the line of leuell directs you to, is iust 100 paces, that summe squared, makes 1000 paces. The like number of paces is found in the line AB, being multiplied in it selfe: these two summes beeing ioyned together, makes 20000 paces, the quadrant root thereof is 141 paces and almost ½, shewing the true distance from you standing to your furthest marke B.

The like order you must obserue to know the iust length of any scaling ladder, to scale the wall of any castle, tower, or towne besieged, in taking the height of the said wall with your quadrant, or otherwise as afore hath beene taught, multiplying that knowne measure in it selfe: and likewise multiplying the distance from the foote of the ladder (or the space betweene the base of the wall and that part of ground where the foote of the ladder stands) in it selfe, adding those two summes together, extracting the square root thereof, your quotient wil tell you the length of your scaling ladder. Or by knowing the length of your scaling ladder and the height of the wall, multiplying euery number in it selfe as aforesaid, abating the lesser summe from the greater, the Quadrant roote of the remaine is the distance of
the ground from the foote of the ladder to the base of the wal. Or by knowing the length of the scaling ladder and the length of the ground from the foote of the ladder to the base of the wall, you may find out the height of the wall, in multiplying each number in it selfe, abating the lesser summe out of the greater, extracting the square roote of the remaine, the quotient will answer your demand, as is demonstrated and proued in the 47 proposition of the first booke of Euclids Elements.

div.head: How you may by the ayde of two staues or Gunners Iauelins perpendicularly erected, by knowing the distance from your standing to the middle part betwixt any two markes, measure the distance betweene the said markes.
div.p:
ADmit the line AB is the 2 markes whose distance I would measure, and the line CD is the knowne measure to the middle part betwixt the said markes, which I suppose to be 200 feete, erect vp the two staues EF, so as the visuall line from your eye at C, passing by the staues, may point directly to the said markes AB.
diagram showing the use of two perpendicular staves or gunner's javelins to measure distance
The distance betwixt the two staues suppose to bee 20 feete, and the distance from your eye to the staues 24 feet; frame the rule of 3, saying, if 24 foot (being the distance from your eye to the staues) yeeld 20 foot (which is the space betwixt either staffe) what will 200 foote (which is the length of the line from C to D?) Multiply 200 by 20, ariseth 4000, diuide by 24, the quotient is 166 feete ⅔, the true distance betwixt the two markes AB which you seeke to measure.

div.head: How you may by the diuisions of the scale of your quadrant, by knowing the distance to any tower, steeple, tree, or other mark, not farre distant, know how much the same is higher or lower than your standing.
div.p: THe distance known, note by what point of the scale of your quadrant the index or threed fals on, in viewing the same marke through the sights on your ruler, by which point or diuision you must diuide 12, (the diuisions of your scale). and note what comes in your quotient, by which quotient number diuide the distance from your standing to the base of the marke, your new quotient number will tell you how much the top of the marke or altitude is higher than your eye.

div.head: Example.
div.p:
THe distance from my standing to the base of the altitude suppose to be 200 feete, the plumline falling on the part 6 of contrarie shadow, I diuide 12 by 6, the quotient is 2, by which quotient number I diuide 200 feet (the space betwixt my standing and the marke, and
so I find 100 in my new quotient: so I affirm the top of the marke was 100 foot higher than my eye. The like is to be done for descents in turning the contrary angle of the quadrant to your eye.

Note that to take the distance betweene any 2 markes with the quadrant, the markes beeing not farre asunder, you must obserue the like order you doe in taking heights, sauing that in measuring heights the quadrant must euer hang so as the plummet and threed hauing libertie to moue to and fro, may euer hang perpendicularly: and to take distances the quadrant must euer lye flat, so as the same doe euer make a square angle against the markes whose distances you would measure: in working whereof an Athilleda, index, or pointer (as some terme it) placed in the center or angle of the quadrant hauing two sights thereon, will direct you much better to the markes than the threed. Many other conclusions are to be found out, and wrought by this instrument: to the ingenious these few may suffice.
